Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Screen.title: LMRKOUT Process
Screen.Label: LMRKOUT -- Trace output directly to SeisWorks 3D (Landmark)
SEISWORKS_PROJECT=
BASENAME=
(e.g. asdm0801.3dv, test.bri, mig.cmp)
SAMPLE_FORMAT=
INLINE_BRICK_DIM =
ZUNIT_FLAG=
CROSSLINE_BRICK_DIM =
TIME_BRICK_DIM =
FIDELITY =
AMP_FACTOR =
TIM_BEG=
TIM_END=
LM_LICENSE_FILE =
OWHOME =
OW_PMPATH =
OW_DDF =
WRITE=
OUT_OF_BOUNDS_IS_FATAL=
OPTIMIZE_INLINE=

Help.Tip: The name of the SeisWorks (3D) Project
Help.Text:
lmrkout - SEISWORKS_PROJECT
The name of the SeisWorks (3D) Project
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Must pre-exist and be NFS mounted.

Help.Tip: Name of output 3D volume set.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - BASENAME
Name of output 3D volume set.
 
 Default = test_f16.bri
 Allowed = Must have extension .3dv, .bri, or .cmp.
 Twelve chars maximum for type .3dv (8 chars max plus '.3dv').

Help.Tip: Available choices depend on BASENAME (.3dv, etc.).
Help.Text:
lmrkout - SAMPLE_FORMAT
Available choices depend on BASENAME (.3dv, etc.).
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 See the ADVICE TO USERS section.

Help.Tip: Number of samps on the side of a brick in the inline dimension.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - INLINE_BRICK_DIM
Number of samps on the side of a brick in the inline dimension.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 1 or higher
 Used for .bri output only.
 See Landmark documentation for detailed format discussion.

Help.Tip: Sets flag in data header describing nature of output data.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - ZUNIT_FLAG
Sets flag in data header describing nature of output data.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Set appropriately to TIME or DEPTH.

Help.Tip: Number of samps on the side of a brick in the crossline dimension.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - CROSSLINE_BRICK_DIM
Number of samps on the side of a brick in the crossline dimension.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 1 or higher
 Used for .bri output only.
 See Landmark documentation for detailed format discussion.

Help.Tip: Number of samps on the side of a brick in the time dimension.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - TIME_BRICK_DIM
Number of samps on the side of a brick in the time dimension.
 
 Default = 16
 Allowed = 1 or higher
 Used for .bri output only.
 See Landmark documentation for detailed format discussion.

Help.Tip: Fidelity factor.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - FIDELITY
Fidelity factor.
 
 Default = 99
 Allowed = 50 <= FIDELITY <= 100
 Used for .cmp output only.

Help.Tip: Multiply amplitudes by this factor before writing the data.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - AMP_FACTOR
Multiply amplitudes by this factor before writing the data.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real
 This scale factor does not affect the amplitudes passing through to
 subsequent processes in the job.

Help.Tip: Start time (or depth) of output volume.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - TIM_BEG
Start time (or depth) of output volume.
 
 Default = global value
 Allowed = sensible
 If appending to existing file, must match existing file.

Help.Tip: End time (or depth) of output volume.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - TIM_END
End time (or depth) of output volume.
 
 Default = global value
 Allowed = sensible
 If appending to existing file, must match existing file.

Help.Tip: Defines the OpenWorks license file.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - LM_LICENSE_FILE
Defines the OpenWorks license file.
 
 Default = Site-specific value stored in cps_config.dat.
 Allowed =
 Necessary for devkit operation.

Help.Tip: Defines the OpenWorks "home path".
Help.Text:
lmrkout - OWHOME
Defines the OpenWorks "home path".
 
 Default = Site-specific value stored in cps_config.dat.
 Allowed =
 Necessary for devkit operation.  Home path for OpenWorks.

Help.Tip: Defines the OpenWorks project management path".
Help.Text:
lmrkout - OW_PMPATH
Defines the OpenWorks project management path".
 
 Default = Site-specific value stored in cps_config.dat.
 Allowed =
 Necessary for devkit operation.  Generally is $OWHOME/conf.

Help.Tip: Defines the 'dir.dat' file.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - OW_DDF
Defines the 'dir.dat' file.
 
 Default = Site-specific.
 Allowed =
 Ask your local Landmark data manager(s) for the correct dir.dat file to use.
 Your site may not want you loading seismic data to $OWHOME/conf/dir.dat.

Help.Tip: Whether to overwrite or append to file set.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - WRITE
Whether to overwrite or append to file set.
 
 Default = NEW
 Allowed = NEW, OVERWRITE

Help.Tip: Abort if line, trace, or time range is out of bounds.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - OUT_OF_BOUNDS_IS_FATAL
Abort if line, trace, or time range is out of bounds.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, NO
 Use YES normally to catch errors like inverted line and trace numbers.

Help.Tip: Design output file to optimize inline IO.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - OPTIMIZE_INLINE
Design output file to optimize inline IO.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES, NO
 In the absence of a very good reason to do otherwise, you should use INLINE
 for 3dv files.  This is the most common preferred interpreter viewing
 direction, and also this is normally the way your input data is sorted.
 In the case of brick files, this parameter is set automatically according to
 the brick DIM values you input.

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
lmrkout - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : LMRKOUT
 Category   : io
 Written    : 2001-07-16   by: SMCook
 Revised    : 2007-01-08   by: Bill Menger
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Write traces directly to SeisWorks 3D.
 Portability: Adaptable to platforms supported by Landmark devkits.
 Parallel   : No
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 Overview
 --------
 
 LMRKOUT is used to write traces directly to an existing SeisWorks 3D project.
 
 The typical application for LMRKOUT is to write out final migrated time or
 depth data in a format that's convenient for the end user.  However, other
 applications are possible and potentially quite useful, such as writing out
 flattened pre-stack gathers to an "AVA cube", allowing an interpreter to
 work on AVA data using familiar tools (amplitude extractions, EarthCube, ...).
 
 Another potentially useful "non-standard" application would be to write out
 an "average velocity cube" that an interpreter could use directly for depth
 conversion (by simply multiplying a time map by an average velocity map).
 
 A certain amount of leg-work is required to run LMRKOUT in the sense that you
 will need to be aware of information such as:
 
   1. the name of the SeisWorks project
 
   2. the names of all existing data volumes (so you don't accidentally
      overwrite someone else's data -- IN CERTAIN MODES LMRKOUT DOES NO
      CHECKING FOR THIS)
 
   3. the amount of disk space available under the project umbrella
 
   4. environment variable settings
 
 Trace output occurs under the umbrella of a pre-existing SEISWORKS_PROJECT
 (created outside of CPS).  You won't be writing traces to the same disks you
 typically write CPS data to.  In fact, you do not specifically define the
 output file names per se.  You provide a BASENAME, and the devkit distributes
 the file extents across externally pre-defined disk partitions allocated to a
 specific SEISWORKS_PROJECT.  These partitions are specified in a configuration
 file known as a "dir.dat" file (further discussed below).  Every Landmark
 installation has at least one dir.dat file, and every office running Landmark
 employs at least one person who knows how to use them.  Find this person.
 
 As with Landmark's "bcm3d" data-loading program, traces are put to disk
 roughly in the order that you write them.  A header file is generated (or
 possibly just updated) during loading that contains the information needed to
 map the traces on disk to their proper geographical positions when viewed in
 SeisWorks.  The existence of this header file is what allows Landmark to store
 irregularly-shaped surveys without storing a bunch of zeroes.  In other words,
 SeisWorks does not assume that a dataset is or ever will be a fully populated
 "cube".  (Please note that the usability of the final product can be greatly
 affected by the trace sorting and choices you make, as per below.)
 
 When writing out "non-standard" products like an AVA cube, you will probably
 need to fudge header words 8 & 7 to mimic some hypothetical inline/crossline
 setup, and you may very well not want to put it into the same SeisWorks
 project as the post-stack data.  [Each office could perhaps set up a "dummy
 project" or two to handle AVA volumes using a standard (1 ... 1000) x
 (1 ... 1000) numbering scheme.  The burden would then be on the end user to
 know where each trace gather belongs geographically.]
 
 
 Sample Formats
 --------------
 
 Conoco implements better data-loading practices than those outlined in
 Landmark's documentation.  Specifically, it is highly recommended that you
 ignore Landmark's advice for setting clip points based on histograms.  It is
 the product of an era in which disk space was far more expensive than today,
 and is incongruous with the ways in which Conoco currently uses its seismic
 data.  Consult the customer and use your own good sense instead.
 
 The following file format / sample format combinations are available:
 
     3DV              BRICKED                COMPRESSED
     ---              -------                ----------
     INT8             BRICKED_FLOAT8         COMPRESSED_FLOAT32
     INT16            BRICKED_FLOAT16
     INT32            BRICKED_FLOAT32
     FLOAT32          INT8  (discouraged)
                      INT16 (discouraged)
 
 A brief description/commentary of each follows.  Preferences are likely to
 change over the years as computers continue to get faster.  Those with
 (**) asterisks are considered the least useful in common situations.
 I/O speed both for you and the end user decreases as you go down the list.
 
 
  3DV's:
  ------
 
    INT8    - "Traditional" 8-bit data.  Fast in optimized direction.  Can be
              the best day-to-day workhorse if amplitudes are balanced (i.e.
              dynamic range is limited), such as with post-MVXP data.
              Particularly justified if interpreter also has access to 16-bit
              or better versions when needed or if it's just used for
              structural interpretation anyway.  Potentially dangerous if no
              other data is delivered.  Clipping at 25 times the median is
              currently common within Conoco (if data has had MVXP applied).
 
    INT16   - "Traditional" 16-bit data.  Fast in optimized direction.  Fine
              for the majority of post-stack situations, assuming minimal
              (better yet no) clipping during the loading/creation step,
              assuming the data doesn't have strong amplitude decay or large
              useful dynamic range for some other reason, and assuming no
              unusual further specialty processing is planned (separation of
              upgoing from downgoing energy, multiple removal, etc.).
 
 ** INT32   - Rarely used since it occupies same space as floating point.
 
    FLOAT32 - Full 32-bit IEEE values.  Fast in optimized direction, no data
              loss.
 
 
  Bricked:
  --------
 
    INT8          - Similar to 3DV INT8, but numbers are returned within the
                    devkit as floats.  Using BRICK_FLOAT8 is normally better.
 
    INT16         - Similar to 3DV INT16, but numbers are returned within the
                    devkit as floats.  Using BRICK_FLOAT16 is normally better.
 
    BRICK_FLOAT8  - Each brick takes advantage of all 8 bits by storing values
                    from -128 to 127 plus a local scale factor.  Worth
                    considering.
 
    BRICK_FLOAT16 - Each brick takes advantage of all 16 bits by storing
                    values from -32768 to 32767 and a local scale factor.
                    Effectively yields floating point precision.  Very
                    sensible format.  Not unlike PROMAX trace storage.  Note
                    also that there's no reason a "brick" can't just be a
                    single trace, in which case each trace essentially just
                    gets loaded unclipped and has a single scale factor.  This
                    is the default approach in LMRKOUT for '.bri' files.
 
 ** BRICK_FLOAT32 - Each brick uses all 32 bits and has its own local scale
                    factor.  Yields higher precision than regular floating
                    point (overkill, in other words).
 
  Compressed:
  -----------
 
    COMPRESSED_FLOAT32 - Disk savings is impressive.  Distortion is normally
                         very acceptable (percent FIDELITY to retain is
                         controlled by the user).  However, can suffer from
                         significant speed degradation both for this CPS
                         process and for the final user.  CPU-intensive to
                         decompress, slightly ahead of its time, perhaps.
                         Currently more popular with IM departments than with
                         interpreters.  Good choice in some circumstances, the
                         only choice in others.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 NOTES:
 
 1. Traces coming into LMRKOUT should be sorted as though you were cutting a
    typical final SEGY tape, i.e. you should be dumping all the data for an
    inline, then all the data for the next inline, etc.  Crossline numbers
    should change monotonically within each inline and do so in a consistent
    manner.
 
    Minor deviations from this pattern are probably acceptable, but beware that
    significant I/O inefficiencies will be created for the end user if the file
    isn't logically organized.
 
    SeisWorks does allow files to be written in a manner optimized for
    crossline viewing rather than inline viewing.  In the interest of keeping
    LMRKOUT easy for day-to-day use, using this capability is somewhat
    discouraged.  References to it were placed in the "Seldom Changed" box.
    If you use this option, you may want to presort the input data into
    crossline chunks rather than inline chunks (input sort order doesn't affect
    the output, but can make your CPS job run better).
 
 2. LMRKOUT cannot create new SeisWorks projects.  Creating a new SeisWorks
    project is typically handled by a geotechnician, or someone else with the
    appropriate permissions and training.
 
 3. It is possible that you will want to preceed LMRKOUT by SELECT.  You must
    restrict the traces coming in to the LMRKOUT (as defined by header words
    8 and 7) such they do not exceed the inline and crossline ranges of the
    project.  The job will abort if you attempt to load a trace that is outside
    of the project bounds (unless you set OUT_OF_BOUNDS_IS_FATAL_ERROR to NO).
 
 
 POSSIBLE WORK FLOW:
 
 1. Ask the appropriate party whether SeisWorks project XYZ has enough disk
    space to accomplish the task at hand.  He or she will need to consult the
    dir.dat file for the project, checking for possible read-only permissions,
    and possibly making adjustments to prepare for your output.  Make sure you
    use the right dir.dat file -- special data-loading versions may exist.
 
 2. Check the project boundaries (fire up SeisWorks yourself or again solicit
    help).  Make sure the values in header words 8 and 7 do not define traces
    that are outside of the inline and crossline ranges defined for the
    project.  If some are, be aware of variable OUT_OF_BOUNDS_IS_FATAL_ERROR.
 
 3. If appending to an existing seismic data volume, make sure the time (or
    depth) range and sample rates match those of your traces.  If not, use
    TSEL, etc. to force consistency.
 
 4. To reiterate, if not outputting floating point data, intelligent sample
    format and amplitude choices will need to be made.  Make them.
 
 5. For large jobs, you may want to run a small test first if possible.  Then,
    be sure to use WRITE = OVERWRITE so the program doesn't abort due to the
    pre-existing files.
 
 6. The potential for visually monitoring the progress of the job does exist.
    There is no general restriction against opening SeisWorks and "watching
    the data load."  However, this can be somewhat fickle, and almost certainly
    won't work until a fair amount of data has been written, and may not work
    at all for bricked and compressed files.
 
 
 SCALING EXAMPLES:
 
 *****************************************************************************
  To write out an unclipped INT16 .3dv volume, set AMP_FACTOR to be equal to
  (32767 / max_absolute_amp_in_dataset).  This will avoid clipping.
 *****************************************************************************
 
 *****************************************************************************
  To write out an unclipped FLOAT16 .bri volume, set AMP_FACTOR to whatever
  you want (each brick carries its own local scale factor anyway), but
  typically 1.0.
 *****************************************************************************
 
 *****************************************************************************
  To write out an INT8 .3dv volume clipped at 25 times the median, insert
  MVXP into the flow (immediately?) prior to LMRKOUT then, assuming the median
  of the data is now 1.0, set AMP_FACTOR to (127 / 25), also known as 5.08.
 
  To write out an INT16 volume clipped at 25 times the median, again assuming
  the median of the data is 1.0, you'd use an AMP_FACTOR = (32767 / 25), also
  known as 1310.68.
 
  INT32 is available but rarely (if ever) used.
 *****************************************************************************
 
 *****************************************************************************
  To write out any of the various FLOAT32 approaches, you'd typically just
  set AMP_FACTOR to be equal to 1.0.
 *****************************************************************************
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                             REVISION HISTORY
 
     Date        Author     Description
     ----        ------     -----------
 22. 2007-01-08  Bill Menger Modified tim_end using ameq function so that it
                             won't crater when the user has depth steps that
                             round off funny.
 21. 2006-02-14  SMCook     Added ZUNIT_FLAG.
 20. 2006-01-03  SMCook     Changed min_amp_written and max_amp_written
                             initializations to give meaningful printout when
                             loading "non-standard" data such as velocities.
 19. 2004-08-11  SMCook     Enabled INT8 and INT16 bricked options, which were
                             intentionally omitted in the original version.
                            Added inline_inc, crossline_inc arguments.
 18. 2004-05-11  SMCook     Changed max 3dv chars from 12 to 34.
 17. 2004-04-27  SMCook     Changed brick default dimensions to 8x8x16, plus
                             made minor doc and field sensitivity changes.
 16. 2003-11-19  SMCook     Modified OB trace logic to include return values
                             1, 2, and 3 (formerly 3 only).
                            Added new variable out_of_bounds_print so that
                             more than one warning message will appear if
                             there are a lot of OB traces.
 15. 2003-08-06  SMCook     Corrected erroneous statement that inline
                             optimization affects only .3dv files.  Turns out
                             it actually also affects the memory cache used
                             for bricked and compressed files.  For bricked
                             files, LMRKOUT now sets optimization parameter
                             based on the type of brick dimensions the user
                             supplies.  User is warned about trace sorting if
                             LMRKOUT changes the optimization setting.
 14. 2003-06-30  SMCook     Gave user a choice whether an OB trace is a
                             fatal error or not.
                            Changed doc to mention that inline optimization
                             currently only applies to 3dv files.
 13. 2003-06-25  SMCook     Inform user what the line, trace, and time values
                             were when an "out of survey bounds" error is
                             returned from the devkit.
 12. 2003-06-16  SMCook     Moved putenv statements so they run before traps.
                            Removed seisworks_project_trap.
                            Fixed create_if_absent logic.
 11. 2003-04-14  SMCook     Split up options NEW and OVERWRITE for protection
                             against overwriting another's Landmark volume.
 10. 2003-02-12  SMCook     Changed documentation to reflect the fact that
                             lmrkwrap.f90 now obtains the Landmark environment
                             variable defaults from cps_config.dat.
  9. 2003-01-15  SMCook     Added logic for LM_LICENSE_FILE.  Overrides and
                             eliminates need for it in the job builder.
  8. 2002-07-16  SMCook     Initialized max_amp_written (to 0).
                            User stats now show both the min and max scaled
                             amplitudes written to the output volume.
                             Previously, only the max was printed out for the
                             user.  This was potentially confusing since the
                             user might typically be more interested in knowing
                             the absolute max.
  7. 2002-02-08  SMCook     Increased length allowed for output filename to 60.
                             Changed the guidef slightly to accomodate this
                             change (note that there is still a Landmark-
                             imposed file name length limit for 3dv files).
  6. 2001-10-09  SMCook     Now prints stats like line range, crossline range,
                             and max amp to the report file every 5000 traces.
                            Fixed GUI bug where FLOAT32 changed back to INT16.
                            Changed OVERWRITE variable from logical YES/NO to
                             NEW/OVERWRITE and APPEND in effort to be more
                             clear to the user.
                            Disabled MAX_EXTENT_SIZE variable due to failure
                             to ever get it to work right.
  5. 2001-08-07  SMCook     Changed trap logic in a number of places to
                             address intermittent GUI crashes.
                            Changed DISTORTION to more-common FIDELITY.
  4. 2001-08-01  SMCook     Fixed BASENAME trap to guarantee valid samp_format.
  3. 2001-07-24  SMCook     Fixed inadvertent omission of call to
                             lmrkwrap_proj_get_path_count.
                            Added '01.3dv' trap -- prevent invalid names.
                            Multiply dt and tstrt by 1000 going to SeisWorks.
  2. 2001-07-19  SMCook     Finished max_extent logic.
                            Now using HDRs 7 & 8 instead of 37 & 38.
  1. 2001-07-16  SMCook     Initial version.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
